factoid: This is the first act.
The acts that follow the first act are increasingly interesting and entertaining.
After the field marshal departed, our forces are within sight of the enemy and must give battle.
Buxhöwden is commander in chief by seniority.
General Bennigsen and his corps are within sight of the enemy and he wishes to profit by fighting a battle on his own hand, as the Germans say.
General Bennigsen fights a battle on his own hand.
The battle of Pultúsk is considered a great victory, but the narrator thinks it was not.
Civilians have a very bad way of deciding whether a battle was won or lost.
According to civilians, those who retreat after a battle have lost it, so they say our forces lost the battle of Pultúsk.
Our forces retreat after the battle but send a courier to Petersburg with news of a victory.
General Bennigsen, hoping to receive the post of commander in chief from Petersburg as a reward for his victory, does not give up command of the army to General Buxhöwden.
During the interregnum, our forces begin a very original and interesting series of maneuvers.
Our aim is to avoid General Buxhöwden, who by seniority should be our chief.
After crossing an unfordable river, our forces burn bridges to separate themselves from their enemy, who is General Buxhöwden.
General Buxhöwden was attacked and captured by a superior enemy force due to one of our maneuvers that enabled us to escape him.
General Buxhöwden pursues our forces, and we scuttle.
General Buxhöwden hardly crosses the river to our side before we recross to the other side.
Our enemy, General Buxhöwden, catches us and attacks.
Both General Buxhöwden and General Bennigsen are angry; General Buxhöwden issues a challenge, and General Bennigsen has an epileptic fit.
The courier returning from Petersburg brings our appointment as commander in chief; General Buxhöwden is vanquished; we can now turn our thoughts to Bonaparte.
A third enemy, Orthodox Russian soldiers, rises before us, loudly demanding bread, meat, biscuits, fodder, and other supplies.
The stores are empty and the roads are impassable.
The Orthodox begin looting in a way that our last campaign cannot explain.
Half of the regiments form bands, scour the countryside, and put everything to fire and sword.
The inhabitants are totally ruined, hospitals overflow with sick, and famine is everywhere.
Twice marauders attack our headquarters, and the commander in chief asks for a battalion to disperse them.
During one of these attacks, marauders carry off my empty portmanteau and my dressing gown.
The Emperor proposes to give all division commanders the right to shoot marauders; I fear this will oblige half the army to shoot the other.
At first Prince Andrew read the letter with his eyes only, but after a while, despite himself, what he had read began to interest him more and more.
After reading thus far, Prince Andrew crumpled the letter and threw it away.
What vexed Prince Andrew was not the content of the letter, but the fact that the life outside, in which he had no part, could perturb him.
Prince Andrew shut his eyes, rubbed his forehead to rid himself of interest in what he had read, and listened to what was happening in the nursery.
Prince Andrew thought he heard a strange noise through the door.
Prince Andrew was seized with alarm that something might have happened to the child while he was reading the letter.
Prince Andrew tiptoed to the nursery door and opened it.
As Prince Andrew entered, he saw the nurse hiding something from him with a scared look, and Princess Mary was no longer by the cot.
Prince Andrew heard what seemed to him Princess Mary's despairing whisper behind him.
After long sleeplessness and anxiety, Prince Andrew was seized by an unreasoning panic, and he thought the child was dead.
Everything Prince Andrew saw and heard seemed to confirm his terror.
